if im willing to put in 5 years to learn 3 or 4 instruments,

      and the level of good i want to get is about to the level where if i started busking people would hear me and they would say something like "wow youre really really good" and then they give 20 dollars. and that repeats with lots or people that walk by. though i think tou might need some more factors to understand if i should pursue music, such as my singing voice. my singing voice is naturally pretty good (for reference it sounds very similar to your voice, but when singing it sounds different to the point where its unique) my voice is suited for more rock and pop type somgs, but i could also try hip hop type songs, but my voice can not do the growling thing that tends to happen in metal songs. i have a keyboard with 61 keys, (though im poor so its not very good) i hope to learn simple songs, and then everything necassa ry for m y journey to success. i know a bit about basic music theory but i dont know how to put it down and do things, and i dont have the muscle memory to always hit the notes im trying to on triads, because i havent even done any real practice. i cant afford lessons right now. i can picture myself being successful to exactlty the degree i want, but i dont know how to get there, or where to start my journey. i havent been involved with music from a young age. my confidence level is about 60%, but when i get my journey started it will definitely be atleast 90%. based on all these factors would it be a good idea to pursue music?

      sorry for writing a very long question, i just had so many things i wanted to say.
thank you


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201911081547

     sure, but i need some more information. first you must tell me how good you're willing to get and how hard you're willing to try

3.15.17  1:04 pm   Can you drop some more mad hints and give us an idea on how close you are to finishing the new History of [blank] video? The last one that really gave us an idea of the progress you made was a checklist comparing it to the one for history of Japan.

     the 'graphics' phase was finished on feb 7. after that, the process is a little bit more confusing to explain. it's a lot of smaller things -- final narration, jingle vocals, editing jingles and narration, mixing, re-alignment to fit final narration timing, and the score. the score is the most subtantial item of all of those, but not as large as 'graphics.' it is hard to exactly explain the process because i have been bouncing around depending on whether it's day or night (vocal recording, etc) and also i was sick and had lingering sick voice for a couple weeks, so during that time i made an early detour into doing the score, somewhere around feb 19. so i basically locked up the narration timing up until 7:50 (that was as far as i had gotten) and started on the score. by the time i reached 7:50 in the score (this was around march 2 i guess), i was able to resume vocals, and was bouncing around between doing jingles and narration. narration is now solidly in place with correct timing, video re-alignment to fit that new timing is done, now starting on the rest of the score, from 8min to the end. once the score is done, it is just the small little tasks like year labels, other labels, graphics adjustments, mixing, etc etc etc but these small tasks tend to fly by very fast, and once the score is done it tends to be a slippery slope to the end of the process. this is what i know from experience on doing the previous long video of this type. i hope that makes sense

(at that point, i will also have a solid estimate of how long it is). the next phase is "prelim graphics collection", which would be finding all the materials i need to download, so in the case of Japan, it would be pictures of emperors and stuff, maps (even if i'm not using the map, i need to find maps that show the proper locations of the things i am mentioning.) 6.21.16  9:02 pm   when do you think your next history video will be done?

      i am about 30 to 45 seconds into the writing. i really like the direction that it is going. i am using the same strategy as i did for history of japan, which is "say as much as you need to say to sufficiently explain the topic FAST and efficiently, but make it as long as you need." when the writing is done, i will do a timed read through and then i will know how long it is. i am guessing it will be anywhere between 5 and 10 minutes. (if i can say everything i want to say in 3, that would be fine too. if it takes 15, ...... i guess that's fine too.) japan clocked in at exactly 9 minutes on the first timed run through. i am also working on this video every day, every available hour (just like the last one.) The main difference between this time and last time is this: during the 14 weeks that it took to make history of japan, i was also writing and creating short videos for vine Every Single Day for about the first 2/3 of the time i was working on history of japan. so that would be maybe about half the work time each day devoted to vine, and NOT the history video. Now i am not doing that. so that would be a significant reason why this video might get done faster. Also, after making history of japan, i have refined some of my techniques a bit more, and might be able to work faster. However, the scope of this topic is a bit different, which might present some unforseen challenges. There is also a small chance that I may decide to make a short video just to have Something to release during the long haul (although i might NOT do that, because that will only directly delay the release of the long video.) The good news is, i have a 1 minute song and music video already completed which i am waiting to upload. i am saving it for when i am deep in the depths of production on this long video, so i have something to release. i hope that answers your question

3.15.17  1:04 pm   Can you drop some more mad hints and give us an idea on how close you are to finishing the new History of [blank] video? The last one that really gave us an idea of the progress you made was a checklist comparing it to the one for history of Japan.

     the 'graphics' phase was finished on feb 7. after that, the process is a little bit more confusing to explain. it's a lot of smaller things -- final narration, jingle vocals, editing jingles and narration, mixing, re-alignment to fit final narration timing, and the score. the score is the most subtantial item of all of those, but not as large as 'graphics.' it is hard to exactly explain the process because i have been bouncing around depending on whether it's day or night (vocal recording, etc) and also i was sick and had lingering sick voice for a couple weeks, so during that time i made an early detour into doing the score, somewhere around feb 19. so i basically locked up the narration timing up until 7:50 (that was as far as i had gotten) and started on the score. by the time i reached 7:50 in the score (this was around march 2 i guess), i was able to resume vocals, and was bouncing around between doing jingles and narration. narration is now solidly in place with correct timing, video re-alignment to fit that new timing is done, now starting on the rest of the score, from 8min to the end. once the score is done, it is just the small little tasks like year labels, other labels, graphics adjustments, mixing, etc etc etc but these small tasks tend to fly by very fast, and once the score is done it tends to be a slippery slope to the end of the process. this is what i know from experience on doing the previous long video of this type. i hope that makes sense

11.5.19  12:12 pm   Bill, you talk about how in order to have absolute pitch, you need some reference point(s) that were instilled from a very young age.       And these songs are ones I have only discovered very recently. So my question: does being able to remember and sing a song in key count as, or at least approximate, absolute pitch?

     to put it to the test you should try to get it to work while another song is playing, and compare it to obtain that song's key. but i will tell you something ironic. you will hear the experts say "no, that doesn't count, that's just sonic memory. the real absolute pitchers can do it instantly." But for me, here's the twist: every single person i've ever met who claims to have absolute pitch, i test them on it and they fail miserably.... by way more than a half step

html:
10.22.19  1:47 pm   10.20.19  5:55 pm   Thanks for the tips, Bill!  I'm currently having some fun writing my song and it may be up on YouTube soon, but I haven't decided the length. Would 7 or 8 seconds work? Or does it need to be 2 seconds? Thanks!
-Misha


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201910201755

10.20.19  5:55 pm   Hi Bill! I have a work in progress song I'm  composing digitally, but there are so many areas I feel uncomfortable with. Any tips for helping me get over my fear of getting into unfamiliar areas of songwriting/making? Thanks!

     if you're feeling overwhelmed, a good catch-all solution for this is to simply start making the songs much shorter. like much shorter. 22 seconds. 12 seconds. ...... still, a lot of unknown fears can lurk even in 12 seconds, so don't be afraid to dial it back to, yep i said it, .... 4 seconds. if you can't do that, then try 3. if you think this is insane, i dare you to not have fun while writing a 2 second song. and this way you'll get to take a tour of the entire songwriting factory, instantly. your level of experience will soon double and triple, effortlessly, as easy as eating grains of rice
